channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Amid Tensions, Israeli Lawmakers Push for More Jewish Access to Sacred Site
item.description: A hard-line Israeli lawmaker toured the contested site with a police escort on Sunday after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called on politicians to show restraint.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Moshe Feiglin, right, an Israeli Parliament member from the Likud Party, near the Western Wall in Jerusalem's Old City on Sunday.

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Kills More Than 50 People
item.description: The attack, which also wounded at least 120 people, occurred near the border with India where a flag-lowering ceremony takes place daily at sunset.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: The bodies of victims of a suicide bombing lay at a hospital in Lahore, Pakistan, on Sunday.

item.title: U.N. Employee Under Treatment for Ebola in France
item.description: The health ministry said in a statement on its website that the patient had contracted the virus in Sierra Leone and was being treated in a military hospital near Paris.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Rebel-Backed Elections Underway in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Separatist leaders portrayed the voting in Donetsk and Luhansk as a capstone to their six-month struggle for independence, and voters said the elections would compel Kiev to negotiate and end the war.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: People lined up to vote in Telmanove in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Briton After Women’s Bodies Are Found in Apartment
item.description: One woman had her throat slashed and the body of the other was found in a suitcase on a balcony.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.N. Panel Issues Its Starkest Warning Yet On Global Warming
item.description: Failure to reduce emissions could threaten society with food shortages, refugee crises, major flooding and mass extinctions, the group of scientists and other experts found.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Machines digging for brown coal in front of a power plant near Grevenbroich, Germany, in April.

item.title: China Approves Security Law Emphasizing Counterespionage
item.description: The change, made official on Saturday, targets foreign spies and their domestic collaborators, reflecting top-level concerns about growing political threats from abroad, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Argentine Judge Orders Arrest of Spanish Ex-Officials
item.description: The judge invoked universal jurisdiction in the case of 20 Franco-era officials accused of torturing dissidents.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Judge María Romilda Servini de Cubría, an Argentine federal judge, talking to reporters in San Sebastián, Spain, in May.

item.title: Netanyahu Urges Restraint in Row Over Sacred Site
item.description: Several lawmakers from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud Party have been among a small but vocal group advocating increased Jewish access and prayer at the site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israelis rally for Yehuda Glick, the target of a suspected assassination attempt who sought greater Jewish access to a sacred site.

item.title: Labour Party Leader Backs Replacing House of Lords
item.description: Ed Miliband, the Labour leader, proposed replacing the House of Lords, which traces its roots to the 14th century, with an American-style elected Senate.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM

item.title: Dog Meat Trade in Thailand Is Under Pressure and May Be Banned
item.description: The police have arrested what they describe as the country’s dog meat kingpins, and the military government is considering banning the trade.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Egypt Sentences 8 in Connection With Same-Sex Wedding
item.description: The verdict was the latest in a crackdown by the authorities against gays.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: The defendants, in a courtroom in Cairo on Friday, were convicted of “inciting debauchery.”

item.title: Clashes on Syrian Border Split Lebanese Town
item.description: The village of Ras Baalbek, Lebanon, is determined to stay out of the Syrian conflict, even as it is pushed toward deeper reliance on one of the combatants, Hezbollah.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Ibrahim Nehmo expressed a shared ambivalence about Hezbollah’s power in the village of Ras Baalbek, Lebanon.

item.title: U.S. Marine Veteran Back Home After Months in Mexican Jail
item.description: Andrew Tahmooressi, held for seven months on weapons charges, arrived in his home state of Florida after a court in Mexico ordered his release.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Electricity Returns to Bangladesh After Power Failure
item.description: The whole country lost power for an hour on Saturday after a transmission line in the grid failed.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: A salesman assisted a customer Saturday in Dhaka, Bangladesh, during a nationwide blackout.

item.title: In Torrent of Rapes in Britain, an Uncomfortable Focus on Race and Ethnicity
item.description: Widespread abuses involving so-called grooming gangs put an uncomfortable spotlight on issues of race, religion and ethnicity — and the slow response of law-enforcement authorities.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: In France, Dam Is the Catalyst for a Flood of Young People’s Anger
item.description: What had been a local protest has turned into a national drama, spawning vigils and front-page news coverage, while prompting criticism of the government of President François Hollande.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: Ulrich Lebeuf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Environmental activists setting up camp Wednesday in Lisle-sur-Tarn, France. The protests have come to embody the disenchantment and anger of young people.

item.title: Quick History: American Partisanship, From Sports to Disease
item.description: This week was a good one for baseball spectators; some politicians burnished their images by embracing the spreading fear of Ebola.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: Buster Posey and Madison Bumgarner of the San Francisco Giants, after winning the 2014 World Series.

item.title: Military Backs an Interim President, but Burkina Faso Remains Unsettled
item.description: The military threw its weight behind one of two high-ranking military officers who had been competing to take over the presidency after President Blaise Compaoré quit.
item.dc:creator: By HERVÉ TAOKO and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Isaac Zida, center, before announcing that he was assuming the duties of head of state to ensure “continuity.”

item.title: Putin's Way: Putin’s Friend Profits in Purge of Schoolbooks
item.description: When the number of approved textbooks for Russia’s 14 million schoolchildren was slashed by more than half, one publisher with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin profited handsomely.
item.dc:creator: By JO BECKER and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and Arkady R. Rotenberg, the chairman of a publishing house that has benefited from government maneuvers. Mr. Rotenberg, a judo sparring partner from Mr. Putin’s youth, has gone from a modest trader to a billionaire during Mr. Putin’s tenure.

item.title: Burkina Faso’s President Resigns, and General Takes Reins
item.description: President Blaise Compaoré quit as violent protests against his 27-year reign in the West African nation showed no signs of winding down.
item.dc:creator: By HERVÉ TAOKO and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People looted what was salvageable inside the burned Parliament in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, a day after protesters stormed the building.

item.title: Ukrainians in the Battered East Scramble in Darkness as Winter Nears
item.description: They are picking up the war-torn pieces in the rebel-held region, hoping someone — whether from Kiev or Moscow — can get essential services running again.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Pirates Free Indian Sailors Held for 4 Years
item.description: Somali pirates have freed seven Indian sailors detained for four years in exchange for an undisclosed ransom, Somali officials and a maritime monitoring group said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Killer of Mounties Sentenced to Life in Prison
item.description: A man convicted of fatally shooting three Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers and wounding two others was sentenced to life in prison with no chance of parole for 75 years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: China: Millions in Cash Found at an Official’s Home
item.description: Investigators in China have found more than $33 million in cash at the home of an energy official accused of receiving bribes, a senior prosecutor said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
